au.com.cybersearch2.classytask

Class WorkerTask<Result>

  • java.lang.Object
    • au.com.cybersearch2.classytask.WorkerTask<Result>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Executable, ThreadMessenger<Result>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DatabaseWorkerTask.TaskImpl, TaskBase

    public abstract class WorkerTask<Result>
extends Object
implements ThreadMessenger<Result>, Executable
    WorkerTask
    Author:
    Romain Guy, Andrew Bowley 25/04/2014

    WorkerTask enables proper and easy use of a non-UI thread. This class allows to perform background operations and publish results on the calling thread without having to manipulate threads and/or handlers.

    A worker task is defined by a computation that runs on a background thread and whose result is published on the calling thread. A worker task is defined by one generic type, called Result, and 3 steps, called onPreExecute, doInBackground and onPostExecute.

    Usage

    WorkerTask must be subclassed to be used. The subclass will override at least one method (doInBackground()), and most often will override a second one (onPostExecute(Object).)

    Here is an example of subclassing:

     private class DownloadFilesTask extends WorkerTask<URL, Long> {
 
     List urls;
     
     public void setUrls(List urls)
     {
         this.urls = urls;
     } 
     
     public File doInBackground() {
         long totalSize = 0;
         for (Url url: urls) {
             totalSize += Downloader.downloadFile(urls);
         }
     }

     public void onPostExecute(Long result) {
         showDialog("Downloaded " + result + " bytes");
     }
 }

    Once created, a task is executed very simply:

     DownloadFilesTask downloadFilesTask = new DownloadFilesTask();
 downloadFilesTask.setUrls(urls);
 downloadFilesTask.execute();

    User task's generic type

    The single type used by a user task is:

    1. Result, the type of the result of the background computation.

    To mark the Result type as unused, simply use the type Void:

     private class MyTask extends WorkerTask

 
    The 3 steps
    
 
    When a user task is executed, the task goes through 3 steps:
    
 
      
     
    1. onPreExecute(), invoked on the caller thread immediately after the task
     is executed. This step is normally used to setup the task, for instance by
     showing a progress bar in the user interface.
      2. 
     
    2. doInBackground(), invoked on the background thread
     immediately after () finishes executing. This step is used
     to perform background computation that can take a long time. The parameters
     of the worker task are passed to this step. The result of the computation must
     be returned by this step and will be passed back to the last step. 
     
    3. (Object), invoked on the caller thread after the background
     computation finishes. The result of the background computation is passed to
     this step as a parameter.
      4. 
 
    

 
    Threading rules
    
 
    There are a few threading rules that must be followed for this class to
 work properly:
    
 
      
     
    • execute() must be invoked on the caller thread.
      • 
     
    • Do not call (), (Object),
     doInBackground()
     manually.
      • 
     
    • The task can be executed only once (an exception will be thrown if
     a second execution is attempted.)
      •

    • Method Detail

      • doInBackground

        public abstract Result doInBackground()
        Override this method to perform a computation on a background thread. Any required parameters will need to be provided as fields belonging to the sub class.
        Returns:
        A result, defined by the subclass of this task.
        See Also:
        onPreExecute(), onPostExecute(Object)

      • onPreExecute

        public void onPreExecute()
        Runs on the UI thread before doInBackground().
        See Also:
        onPostExecute(Object), doInBackground()

      • onPostExecute

        public void onPostExecute(Result result)
        Runs on the UI thread after doInBackground(). The specified result is the value returned by doInBackground() or null if the task was cancelled or an exception occured.
        Parameters:
        result - The result of the operation computed by doInBackground().
        See Also:
        onPreExecute(), doInBackground()

      • execute

        public final WorkerTask<Result> execute()
        Executes the worker task. Any required parameters will need to be provided as fields belonging to the sub class. The task returns itself (this) so that the caller can keep a reference to it.
        Returns:
        This instance of WorkerTask.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If status is either WorkStatus.RUNNING or WorkStatus.FINISHED.

      • cancel

        public final boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning)
        Attempts to cancel execution of this task. This attempt will fail if the task has already completed, already been cancelled, or could not be cancelled for some other reason. If successful, and this task has not started when cancel is called, this task should never run. If the task has already started, then the mayInterruptIfRunning parameter determines whether the thread executing this task should be interrupted in an attempt to stop the task.
        Parameters:
        mayInterruptIfRunning - true if the thread executing this task should be interrupted; otherwise, in-progress tasks are allowed to complete.
        Returns:
        false if the task could not be cancelled, typically because it has already completed normally; true otherwise
        See Also:
        isCancelled(), onCancelled(Object)

      • isCancelled

        public final boolean isCancelled()
        Returns true if this task was cancelled before it completed normally.
        Returns:
        boolean
        See Also:
        cancel(boolean)

        Returns task status

      • onCancelled

        public void onCancelled(Result result)
        Runs on separate thread after cancel(boolean) is invoked.
        Parameters:
        result - The result of the operation computed by doInBackground().
        See Also:
        cancel(boolean), isCancelled()

        public ExecutionException getExecutionException()
